Any integrable function can be approximated by bounded continuous functions,
version in terms of `‚à´`.

For any Normed Additive Commutative Group `E`, any torus integrable function `f` from `‚ÑÇ^n` to `E`, any `‚Ñù^n` vector `R` forming a Normed Space over `‚ÑÇ` and `E`, the function mapping `Œ∏` to the scalar product of `f(Exp(Œ∏‚àòc)‚ä§R`, `I` \* Exp(Œ∏) \* I, where `c` is in `‚ÑÇ^n`, `I` is the imaginary unit, and `Œ∏` is in `[0, 2œÄ]`, is integrable over `[0, 2œÄ]` with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] {f : (Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) ‚Üí E} {c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ} {R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
  [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E],
  TorusIntegrable f c R ‚Üí
    MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn
      (fun Œ∏ => (Finset.univ.prod fun i => ‚Üë(R i) * (‚Üë(Œ∏ i) * Complex.I).exp * Complex.I) ‚Ä¢ f (torusMap c R Œ∏))
      (Set.Icc 0 fun x => 2 * Real.pi) MeasureTheory.volume
name: TorusIntegrable.function_integrable
docString: For any Normed Additive Commutative Group `E`, any torus integrable function `f` from `‚ÑÇ^n` to `E`, any `‚Ñù^n` vector `R` forming a Normed Space over `‚ÑÇ` and `E`, the function mapping `Œ∏` to the scalar product of `f(Exp(Œ∏‚àòc)‚ä§R`, `I` \* Exp(Œ∏) \* I, where `c` is in `‚ÑÇ^n`, `I` is the imaginary unit, and `Œ∏` is in `[0, 2œÄ]`, is integrable over `[0, 2œÄ]` with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ` and `R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] (a : E) (c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) (R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
  TorusIntegrable (fun x => a) c R
name: TorusIntegrable.torusIntegrable_const

In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

The arctan function is a continuous real-valued function.

type: Continuous Real.arctan
name: Real.continuous_arctan
docString: The arctan function is a continuous real-valued function.

This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F]
  [inst_6 : MeasurableSpace E] [inst_7 : BorelSpace E] {f : E ‚Üí F} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure E} {U : Set E},
  IsOpen U ‚Üí
    MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f U Œº ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ (g : E ‚Üí ‚Ñù), ContDiff ‚Ñù ‚ä§ g ‚Üí HasCompactSupport g ‚Üí tsupport g ‚äÜ U ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : E), g x ‚Ä¢ f x ‚àÇŒº = 0) ‚Üí
        ‚àÄ·µê (x : E) ‚àÇŒº, x ‚àà U ‚Üí f x = 0
name: IsOpen.ae_eq_zero_of_integral_contDiff_smul_eq_zero
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.
